column1: Nykøbing Falster (Danish pronunciation: [ˈnyˌkʰøˀpe̝ŋ ˈfælˀstɐ]; originally named Nykøbing) is a southern Danish city
column2: seat of the Guldborgsund kommune. It belongs to Region Sjælland. The city lies on Falster
column3: connected by the 295-meter-long Frederick IX Bridge over the Guldborgsund (Guldborg Strait) waterway to the island of Lolland.   The town has a population of 16
column4: 940 (1 January 2020). Including the satellite town Sundby on the Lolland side

column1: Nykøbing Falster is the largest city on the islands of Lolland and Falster
column2: and is often called "Nykøbing F." to distinguish it from at least two other cities in Denmark with the name of Nykøbing. Nykøbing Falster is the seat of state and regional authorities. In addition to those two namesakes
column3: a city in Sweden is called Nyköping
column4: which means exactly the same in the closely related language.

column1: There is a 0.5 kilometer long commercial district
column2: walking street (gågade) on the Falster side of the city with a wide selection of shops.  At the end of the street is a large plaza where special events are arranged. These include popular late-night events
column3: which are held several times a year. It has a large central library in the center of town.

column1: The town receives many visitors during the summer
column2: especially from Germany.

column1: Nykøbing Falster was founded around a 12th-century medieval castle.  At the end of the 12th century
column2: fortifications were set up on a peninsula on Guldborgsund for protection against the Wends
column3: and these were later converted into Nykøbing Castle. The town of Nykøbing Falster grew up around these fortifications. After the Reformation
column4: the castle was the residence of widowed Danish queens. As several queens of German descent resided here
column5: many Germans came to the town.Situated on a headland
column6: the castle was protected from all sides. In its early days
column7: the castle belonged to the royal house. Medieval documents issued in this region reveal that the royal court regularly visited the castle. This is the castle where Christopher II died (1332) and where Christian V was married (1667). Christian
column8: Prince Elect of Denmark resided here. The castle was chartered in 1539. REF

column1: The castle and the entire crown land on Falster were put up for sale in 1763 to help improve the poor state of government finances. The castle was sold for demolition
column2: and only the modest ruin of one of the towers
column3: Fars Hat (Father’s Hat in Danish) is in existence today.

column2: Nykøbing was the administrative seat of the former county of Storstrøm as well as the Nykøbing Falster municipality.
the former Nykøbing Falster municipality merged with Nysted
column6: and Sydfalster municipalities to form Guldborgsund municipality. This municipal reform
column8: created a municipality with an area of 907 square kilometres (350 sq mi) and a total population of 63
column9: 533 (2005) and will belong to the new Region Sjælland ("Zealand Region"). The former Nykøbing Falster municipality covered an area of 134 square kilometres (52 sq mi) with a total population of 25

column1: The city has a few noteworthy buildings
column2: including a wooden house from 1580 and Czarens Hus ("The Tsar's House")
column3: named in memory of Tsar Peter the Great of Russia
column4: who stayed there in 1716. The most noteworthy attraction is the city's old water tower
column6: which was built in 1909 and remains an icon of the city and the surrounding areas. Today
column7: the water tower houses a small cultural center holding art exhibitions and cultural events.

Nykøbing Falster has a railway station operated by Danish State Railways. It is the terminus for regular local passenger-train services from Copenhagen via Ringsted and Køge. International trains operating between Copenhagen and Hamburg (via the train ferry between Rødby and Puttgarden) also call at the station. The Lollandsbanen also operates a rail service to Nakskov.
